title: Social Trust Trial
outcome: Responding to rising outrage and Council collapse, the city suspends the BCI for a three-week 'social trust trial.' With scores frozen and many checkpoints deactivated, neighborhoods self-organize, reshaping daily routines around cooperation. Former divisions between high- and low-score citizens blur as they share resources. Council members, scrambling to regain relevance, attempt to steer public opinion through official broadcasts. However, as halt period nears its end, deep rifts surface over whether to restore the system. Innovators and frustrated citizens begin drafting alternative models, while Directorate loyalists push for a rapid return to order.

events.description: The BCI scoring system is suspended for three weeks as a 'trust and unity' initiative. City checkpoints and compliance gates are deactivated, while all residents' scores are frozen.
Neighborhood councils form spontaneously, coordinating food distribution, work assignments, and dispute resolution. Formerly segregated citizens start cooperating for shared goals.
Council broadcasts promote the 'success' of the social trust trial, masking rising internal anxiety about loss of control and uncertainty for the initiative's end.
Local assemblies debate the future of BCI, with Innovators proposing alternative, partially human-led governance pilots. Directorate supporters warn of chaos without rapid return to automation.
As the trust trial ends, neighborhoods are divided over whether to support BCI restoration or to advocate for permanent civic self-governance. Tensions mount and political factions realign.
